body: closing for now, feel free to reopen when we get back to this issue
set USE_NVRTC to 0

@pluskid @piiswrong 

I rethinked about this issue, it was due to the fact the input arguments(data of different timestamps)(which are binded) is not shared across buckets because they are not allocated by the executor, instead passed in by outside, thus was not shard.
The memory goes back to mxnet's internal memory pool, which will be reused for new arrays. But they are not freed to cuda runtime because cuda's runtime allocation was slow
@tqchen They can still be shared, but the front end need to handle it. executor.reshape does this
The custom op already support this

Hi, I met a similar problem here. My OS is Ubuntu 15.10 x86_64. My gcc is 4.9.3. My CUDA is 7.5.17, my OpenCV is 2.4.9. If I `make -j4` with "OpenCV=0" everything goes well. However, if I `make -j4` with "OpenCV=1", I met a error `
Makefile:203: recipe for target 'bin/im2rec' failed
make: *** [bin/im2rec] Error 1
` I search for google for several days but no answer solve this problem. Could anyone help me? thanks!
@piiswrong That's great! I'll try the custom op. Could I directly transfer the current NumpyOp to CustomOp?

So this would supersede both `NativeOp` and `NDArrayOp` and from looking over the code it seems that it also addresses the issues I had with porting this to the Julia side. Will give it another try after this has been merged.
Thanks. I am looking forward to this feature.
Still the same error, this seems not work for me:(
You just need to split forward/backward into a new class
@tqchen @piiswrong it is fixed now
PR submitted.

Update

About OpenCV, I used `sudo apt-get install libopencv-dev` to install it. And when I used `pkg-config --cflags opencv` to locate the file, the output is `-I/usr/include/opencv`.  However, when I went into `/usr/include` I found there are two files named `opencv` and `opencv2` repectively. 

After I added either of the two file's absolute path into config.mk's  `ADD_LDFLAGS` and `ADD_CFLAGS`, the make result was `make[1]: Leaving directory '/home/zhaoxiaoming/mxnet/dmlc-core'`. But to my surprise,  I was able to use the mnist dataset example now. 

Anyone could help me about this problem? Is there something wrong with the setting?
I guess you have opencv3, if so, try to add `-limgcodecs` to `ADD_LDFLAGS =` in your make configuration.

I have the same problem on another projects with caffe.

Results  significantly differs with cuDNN on/off (better precision with cuDNN off).

You may try to train model without cuDNN, and verify the consistence on gpu and cpu.

As I know, Mxnet doesn't take lmdb(or leveldb) as data backend which is used by caffe.

But it uses a unique data IO module to tackle the bottle-neck of training big models, the database files usually end with '.rec', which can be easily generated by mxnet_root/bin/im2rec.

```
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status

```

and

```
/usr/bin/ld: cannot find -limgcodecs
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
Makefile:203: recipe for target 'bin/im2rec' failed
make: *** [bin/im2rec] Error 1

```
Thanks for the quick reply. But wouldn't be nice if they are using the same dataset format. ImageNet are pretty large dataset.

Hello,

After I have successfully compiled it with CMake, there is no such a file named mxnet_root/bin/im2rec. 
Could you please provide more info? Thanks.

Yes, bucketing also tries to share the inputs. 
1. If it is the inputs with the same name and same shape, they are just shared.
2. If it is the inputs with the same name but smaller shape, then a subset of the existing array is used for sharing. (This is why we now encourage to set the `default_bucket_key` to correspond to the largest bucket.
closing for now if CustomOp already solved the problem
I see, so I guess if user set default to largest key, this problem is kinda of already resolved? if so I will close this issue
Thanks! this is now merged
One thing we might try, is to simply manually delete the cudnn_batchnorm.cu and mxrtc.cc and clean and recompile again
please check why the python test fails. Note that if bcast do not support inplace, inplace declaration should be disabled

Hi Depeng,

Sorry for late reply. I guess this issue is caused by queue blocking somewhere. Could you open an issue on https://github.com/travis-ci/travis-ci/issues or email support@travis-ci.com to see if they have any idea?
Use the python version tools/im2rec.py
okI will open an issue.
@hjk41 can you update the status on this?

Thanks for bring this up. These should be fixed by https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2065

You are more than welcomed to add guide of newly added operator_util.h I can help review and answer any of your questions. Thanks!

softmax_cross_entropy outputs the entropy values, you will need to backprop a head_gradient value. Alternatively, you can stack it with a http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/symbol.html#mxnet.symbol.MakeLoss operator
Note that since softmax_cross_entropy outputs the loss values, it might not be compatible with the evaluation metrics provided. In normal cases softmaxOutput is better

@Xiaoming-Zhao Trying to checkout your opencv library directory(usually `/usr/lib`, `/usr/local/lib`) and locate the file 'opencv_imgcodecs.so'.

ld errors with 'cannot find xxx' usually means your library files are not in the searching directory.
Try momentum with 0.5, or a smaller lr

Hi @lyttonhao 

I tried your code on my own dataset, I create train.rec val.rec with label_width=2 option, and  use ImageRecorderIter as below

``` python
def mnist_iterator(batch_size, input_shape):
    data_shape = input_shape
    train = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = "./train.rec",
        #path_imglist="./train_train.txt",
        mean_r      = 123.68,
        mean_g      = 116.779,
        mean_b      = 103.939,
        data_shape  = data_shape,
        batch_size  = batch_size,
        rand_crop   = True,
        rand_mirror = True,
        label_width = 2
        )

    val = mx.io.ImageRecordIter(
        path_imgrec = "./val.rec",
        #path_imglist="./train_val.txt",
        mean_r      = 123.68,
        mean_g      = 116.779,
        mean_b      = 103.939,
        rand_crop   = False,
        rand_mirror = False,
        data_shape  = data_shape,
        batch_size  = batch_size,
        label_width = 2
        )
    return (train, val)
```

train_train.txt looks like below

> #image_index label1_id label2_id image_path
> 24309  50  1   /female/star/User1/0.jpg
> 24939  51  0   /male/star/User2/0.jpg

I change input_shape  to (3, 28, 28)

after execute python example_multi_task.py I find Train-multi-accuracy_0 and Train-multi-accuracy_1, Validation-multi-accuracy_0 and Validation-multi-accuracy_1 are exactly same, so I think label_2 is not correctly loaded, your code use label_1 always.

Do you have any updated code that can make multi-label classification  work correctly?
Thank you!
Yes. I intend to deprecate those after we fix the interface for this.

`pkg-config --libs opencv`.

**## System**:
 Ubuntu 14.04
gcc version 4.8.4

**## config.mk**:
USE_CUDA = 1
USE_CUDA_PATH = /usr/local/cuda-7.5

UNAME_S := $(shell uname -s)
ifeq ($(UNAME_S), Darwin)
USE_BLAS = apple
else

endif
The first merge request has been merged into mshadow. I opened the second one for MXNet. See https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/2069
Moved the test, as requested..
@kadeng can you test locally why the test_operators failed?

The implicit copy of the attributes to implicitly created children was expected behavior. 
This was used to support, say set learning rate in the convolution operators, without creating the weight explicitly.  I do not have a good idea on better alternatives. 

I agree that list_attrs may need a better separator than underscore. We can fix a convention. `/`(used by tf). `:` or `.` all works for me

hi, thanks for the commit!
I wonder which kind of evaluating metrics should I use when using make loss op?

You can directly set 'weight_lr_mult': 0.01 to change attributes for implicit created variables.
I guess the only use case for copying is group ctx
It depends on what to evaluate. For smooth l1 loss, there is no need for special metric since raw output is enough (the loss value).
We are also using it to freeze parameters during training with the Julia bindings. https://github.com/dmlc/MXNet.jl/pull/87, increasing efficiency for iterative model building.

We should have a DummyMetric that just print the output value. The Torch
metric sort of does this. Can can make a alias and better document it

On Sun, May 8, 2016 at 8:35 PM, Jian Guo notifications@github.com wrote:

> It depends on what to evaluate. For smooth l1 loss, there is no need for
> special metric since raw output is enough (the loss value).
> 
> 
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/pull/1953#issuecomment-217769643
Thanks a lot! @precedenceguo

Sorry I don't exactly understand how this works yet. 
If the smooth l1 op produced a (w, h) tensor, and make loss op take it as an input. So, the output tensor will also be (w, h) dim. Do you mean that this output tensor is the loss value?  And if i want to get the total loss value(a single number), should I sum the output tensor? @precedenceguo
The output is element-wise loss. Sum the output will give a single number.

Can we reopen this so that we have a reminder to fix the `num_filter` issue?

@pluskid The error for this on the Julia side was quite opaque `ERROR: LoadError: DivideError: integer division error` and just stalled the process.
Here is the code snippet: https://github.com/Zondabb/mxnet_cudnn_test @piiswrong @tqchen
do you use raw data or data in format ( e.g. JPEG) ? different device maybe lead to different decoding result
Found the problem, had to do with me not being used to working with git submodules until now. All checks pass now, and it should be safe to merge..
Oh, sorry for this. There is no package for R 3.3.0 right now. I will update soon.

I was able to solve the above issue.
There was some issue due to kernel_size in global pooling layer. Extra padding in convolution layer was causing more no. of filter maps than required.

Now, I am stuck at another issue in the same architecture which causes all the probabilities to be 1.0 for all the classes in output, what could be the possible reason? Any help appreciated!

I don't know of any benchmark but here are a few tips for performance: set MXNET_ENGINE_TYPE=NaiveEngine and compile with openmp
The `params` is a dictionary of NDarray, you can set value and bind to new model.

There is an iOS example: https://github.com/pppoe/WhatsThis-iOS

Note it is running Inception-Batch Norm model, and I don't think this example are using muti-cores.
This has been merged now, so the issue can be closed.

what's the current state of the art on TIMIT?
could it be possible to get them equal? I noticed this problem in my previous experiment in #1981. The get_cost function parsed the debug_str to give a memory estimation.
@piiswrong 16%17% using bidirectional LSTM.
echo @antinucleon debug_str only amounts to the static allocation part of intermediate results, the real execution memory cost is going to be larger.
rescale_grad doesn't have a default value. It needs to be 1/batch_size
@pluskid any luck trying the memonger to save memory cost of long LSTM?

@tqchen, not tried yet. The bucketing up to 800 frame already works quite well. Due to exploding gradient problem we switched to truncated bptt with only 20 frame unroll. It takes quite small memory even without applying memonger--currently we are running at the same speed as cntk but using only half of the memory.

I think that (memonger) is more useful for the sequence level training
(e.g. bi-directional training).

Got it. Thank you. But is there an image list provided for the imagenet? Thank you.
I have fix the problem. Will submit pull request soon.

Yes, we are preferring bptt for gradient exploding reason. But there are more complicated scenarios that might not be easy to do with bptt as Yu pointed out
- bi-directional RNNs
- Sequence training (the loss function, unlike frame-wise softmax, is not easily decomposable according to the frames)
- end-to-end

So bucketing is needed for those complicated scenarios and memonger should prove to be useful in those cases.
